Award.AwardTitle: ADVANCE IT-Catalyst: Transforming Faculty Gender Diversity at Florida Atlantic University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Florida Atlantic University (FAU) will implement an ADVANCE Institutional Transformation-Catalyst (IT-Catalyst) project to undertake institutional self-assessment activities and pilot best practices from ADVANCE institutions. FAU is an urban, minority-serving institution that has faced challenges in recruiting and retaining women faculty, particularly those from URM groups. FAU will administer baseline and follow-up surveys of tenure track and non-tenure track faculty, conduct an institutional policy review, review ADVANCE best practices, choose practices to pilot, and evaluate these strategies using institutional and survey data.

FAU's team aims to leverage two existing initiatives, broadening their foci to include women and URM STEM faculty: a research mentoring program in which senior faculty are paired with junior faculty to develop proposals, and a leadership development program which will also now include training for department heads on recruiting and retaining women and URM faculty. An on-campus AWIS taskforce will also visit other ADVANCE institutions to learn about best practices and will also sponsor AWIS workshops. FAU's administrative and institutional leaders have communicated their commitment to the project and to the adoption of ADVANCE best practices.

The ADVANCE program is focused on developing systemic approaches to increase the participation, retention, and advancement of women in academic STEM careers. The IT-Catalyst track funds projects that aim to conduct institutional self-assessments and implement ADVANCE strategies that have been shown to be effective to address gendered issues for STEM faculty.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ADVANCE IT-Catalyst project at Florida Atlantic University (FAU) accomplished the following project goals, and specific objectives:

1) Completed a base-line evaluation of STEM and non-STEM faculty climate that indicated participation, and perception outcomes were in alignment with trends reported nationally.

2) Conducted site visits and consulted with five other ADVANCE awardee institutions to learn from their experiences of implementing ADVANCE best practices, especially in regards to (a) mentoring programs, (b) revision of recruitment, promotion, and work-family policies, and (c) other professional development initiatives. Institutions visited in-person: University of Maryland, and University of Michigan. Institutions consulted via email/phone: University of Madison-Wisconsin, West Virginia University, and University of West Florida.

2) Conducted a self-assessment of policies and procedures governing hiring, retention, and promotion of FAU STEM (and non-STEM) faculty, and in particular the impacts such policies and procedures may have on STEM faculty who are women and underrepresented minorities (URMs). Our assessment was indicative of the need for change that, in conjunction with lessons learned about what worked and did not work initiative-wise, we pursued and accomplished a systematic change of how we evaluate policies and procedures and how we implement changes to these (per next accomplished goal).

3) Implemented a multi-pronged collaborative infrastructure at FAU to enable a continuous evaluation, review, and possible change of policies and procedures with formative input/feedback from key stakeholder groups, that were formed as part of this project, and from other stakeholders at FAU. The infrastructure of interlinked stakeholders and active faculty leader groups formed as part of this project includes: advanceFAU leadership team (LT), Internal Advisory Committee (IAC) comprised of faculty leaders and administrators, the Strategies and Tactics for Recruiting to Improve Diversity and Excellence (STRIDE) committee, and the inaugural Association of Women in Science (AWIS) National Chapter at FAU. The key stakeholder groups from FAU that now closely and collaboratively work with the newly formed ADVANCE-initiated stakeholder groups are: Provost Office, Institutional Effectiveness and Analysis (IEA), Division of Research (DR), “Circle of Chairs” committee, Division of Public Affairs, Division of Student Affairs and Enrollment Management, and the Diversity Platform.

5) Implemented chosen pilot ADVANCE best practices at FAU, including the STRIDE committee and associated diversity training with respect to the faculty hiring process; a mentoring program jointly sponsored with FAU’s DR; and in collaboration with our institutional partners and key stakeholders (per above point), other professional development and leadership training events for URM, and women STEM faculty, and all faculty at FAU. The STRIDE workshop evaluations in particular showed that positive changes are taking place in attitudes and practice of our faculty and administrators with respect to recruitment of new faculty.

6) In collboration with IEA the advanceFAU LT built a new internal Faculty Dashboard, a first at FAU. This dashboard reports-out validated and accurate data with respect to faculty diversity, tenure status, promotion status, and retention. The advanceFAU LT can now easily download reports, and track progress over time (starting with 2012-13 academic year) with respect to faculty diversity, tenure/promotion status, and other attributes in alignment with the ADVANCE toolkit metrics. This will allow us to better quantify the positive impacts (in particular for URM and women STEM faculty) of current and future ADVANCE-initiated initiatives, professional development programs, as well as changes in policy and procedures relating to faculty hiring, promotion, and retention.

As a result of this project FAU is transforming and embracing the ADVANCE spirit and best practices, and we are now poised to apply for the next level of NSF ADVANCE funding, and ready to expand ADVANCE best practices and approaches even more pervasively at our institution.
